headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Marriott International Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to the President and Chief Operating Officer, Arne
componenttext: Welcome to the Marriott International Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to the President and Chief Operating Officer, Arne Sorenson. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to our second quarter 2011 earnings conference call. Joining me today are Carl Berquist, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Laura Paugh, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations; and Betsy
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to our second quarter 2011 earnings conference call. Joining me today are Carl Berquist, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Laura Paugh, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations; and Betsy Dahm, Senior Director, Investor Relations. Special guests today are Steve Weisz, who will be President and Chief Executive Officer of Marriott Vacations Worldwide; and John Geller, who will serve as Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer for Marriott Vacations Worldwide.
As always, before we get into the discussion of our results, let me first remind everyone that many of our comments today are not historical facts and are considered forward-looking statements under Federal Securities laws. These statements are subject to numerous risks and uncertainties as described in our SEC filings, which could cause future results to differ materially from those expressed in or implied by our comments.  
Forward-looking statements in the press release that we issued last night, along with our comments today, are effective only today, July 14, 2011 and will not be updated as actual events unfold. You can find a reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures referred to in our remarks on our website at www.marriot.com/investor. 
One special clarification as we start the call this morning. Unfortunately, we have 2 press releases that are out there this morning. The correct press release went out on PR Newswire and by fax and was filed with the SEC late yesterday. An earlier draft of the press release was posted on our corporate website. That has since been taken down and replaced with the accurate and current press release. For those of you who pulled the press release off our corporate website last night, you should presume you've got the wrong one and make sure that you get the right one, and of course, we are standing by today to take your calls and to make sure that you got the correct press release. We apologize for any confusion with the posting of that earlier draft may have caused. 
One year ago, at the NYU Hospitality Conference, I was asked about the prospect for the U.S. lodging industry. I responded that I was wildly optimistic. At the time, there was considerable uncertainty about the pace of the recovery but the long-term opportunity was obvious. More recently, I was asked by an investor if I was still wildly optimistic. While uncertainty is still very much in the picture, given recent mixed economic news and ongoing world events, I remain very bullish about the long-term prospects for the lodging industry in general and for Marriott in particular. With strong demand and a prospect for low-supply growth, we are marching steadily towards a return to peak 2007 REVPAR. 
Returns to 2007  peak profitability per room for our owners and for Marriott will take a bit longer, but as profitability improves and we consider the contribution of the roughly 100,000 net additional rooms we have added to our systems since 2007, to say nothing of the 30,000-plus rooms we opened each year going forward, the earnings potential of Marriott is ample cause for significant optimism. 
We've come a long way over that last year. Transient business is back in a big way. The 2011 transient occupancy rate for the Marriott brand increased 3.5 percentage points, reaching 2007 peak Transient occupancy levels this quarter. Overall, Transient REVPAR rose 7% for company-operated Marriotts in North America. Systemwide REVPAR for our limited service hotels in North America increased about 7%, on top of a roughly 5% improvement in 2010. 
Second quarter results in international markets reflected a combination of economic recovery in developed countries and extraordinary economic growth in emerging markets. Excluding the Middle East and Japan, international REVPAR increased over 12% or nearly 18%, including the currency impact. 
We opened over 32,000 rooms in the last 12 months, roughly a 4.5% net unit growth rate. Our development pipeline increased to more than 100,000 rooms, with nearly 40% of our rooms in the full service pipeline in China and India. Our development pipeline in China grew by over 25% in the last 3 months alone. Later this year, we expect to introduce a newly-designed Courtyard prototype specifically tailored for the Chinese market, which should further accelerate our development in that country. 
Our Autograph brand is breaking records. Autograph REVPAR, not included in our comparable REVPAR statistics, rose an amazing 19% for the 3 months ending in May, with REVPAR index up 8 points, our fastest launch ever in just 16 months, we've added 20 hotels to the collection, including 4 Autographs in Europe, and we expect to have about 40 properties opened or signed by year end 2011. 
We continue to control costs. Operating margins of our company-operated hotels improved in the second quarter, and Marriott International's adjusted pretax margin, excluding the impact of reimbursed costs, also improved, reaching close to 24% in the quarter compared to 22% in the prior year.  
And finally, we are returning cash to our shareholders, a lot of cash. Year-to-date, we have returned over $700 million in share repurchases and dividends to shareholders, and we remain committed to do more. 
We're very proud of our second quarter accomplishments. The foundations of these successes were laid long ago. We began our journey to the asset light in 1973 when we signed our first hotel management agreement. Since then, we've grown our system from 11,000 rooms to over 630,000 rooms and increased net income twenty-fold. 
Several key strategies contributed to our success. First, our brands are outstanding. We ensure our brand stay current and deliver value to our guests by frequent renovations and repositions. We tailor new brands and designs to local customers around the world, most recently in India, China, Brazil and Spain. 
Second, high-quality contracts support high-quality brands. Our management franchise agreements are long and stable, typically with initial terms of 20 to 30 years. Brand standards are an important element of every contract. In this industry, poorly-positioned hotels and short-term or terminable contracts can have a lingering negative impact. We want to ensure that each hotel and each relationship enhances the value of our system and bring strong value to us, to our customers and to our owners. 
Third, successful lodging brands need to grow. Guest preference for our brand can't be maintained if the guests cannot find their favorite hotel in the markets where they travel. We've averaged about 4.5% net rooms growth annually for the past 10 years, and we continue to add hotels even in the U.S. where supply growth is very low. 
Fourth and related to number 3, tied-up capital and permanent real estate investment slows growth and depresses ROIC. So we are selective in our use of Marriott capital, and we recycle our investments as a regular practice. As a result, we generated considerable amount of our cash over time. In the nearly 40 years since we signed our first management agreement, we have returned over $12 billion to our shareholders through share repurchases and dividends, not to mention the value we have delivered to our shareholders through spinoffs and substantial capital appreciation. 
Fundamentally, the foundation of our company is based on our people: service culture, brand commitment, innovation and our long-term focus on owner and shareholder returns. Ultimately, these are why we and our owners have greater opportunities for growth ahead. To say more about the second quarter, I'd like to turn the call over to Carl Berquist. Carl?

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Arne. In the second quarter, we reported diluted earnings per share of $0.37, a 19% increase from prior year. We're about $0.01 favorable to the midpoint of our $0.34 to $0.38 paper guidance. Fee revenue was about $0.01 shy, largely related to wea
componenttext:
Thanks, Arne. In the second quarter, we reported diluted earnings per share of $0.37, a 19% increase from prior year. We're about $0.01 favorable to the midpoint of our $0.34 to $0.38 paper guidance. Fee revenue was about $0.01 shy, largely related to weaker-than-expected REVPAR in the D.C. market. Timeshare sales and services net was about $0.02 lower than expected, largely due to reportability. We expect about half of this shortfall will turn around later this year and the remainder next year. 
On the plus side, G&A was about $0.02 better than expected due to several nonroutine items, including a reversal of an earlier loan loss provision. Our tax line contributed about $0.01 favorable, associated with some discrete tax items, and our ongoing share repurchases contributed about $0.01. 
North American Transient demand was very strong in the second quarter. Systemwide North American REVPAR rose 6.6%, with most markets showing significant REVPAR improvement, including double-digit REVPAR growth in Southern Florida, Houston, San Francisco and the California Desert. 
In the past 2 years, one of the strongest markets had been Washington D.C. Even in the second quarter, REVPAR was ahead of the 2007 peak levels. At the same time, second quarter D.C. systemwide REVPAR rose only 1%, reflecting the short and congressional calendar, ongoing budget battle and hesitant federal agencies reluctant to book near-term group business. 
And Washington is an important market to us. Approximately 5% of our domestic systemwide room are located in the greater Washington D.C. market, considerably higher than the industry's contemplation. And the market is more important to us than even the room's distribution implies.  In 2010, approximately 6% of our worldwide fee revenue came from this market and 13% of our incentive fees. Based on our long experience in this market though, Washington is also very resilient, and we remain very optimistic about its long-term prospects. 
Across North America, second quarter group REVPAR at the Marriott brand increased 2% year-over-year. Our sales executives are doing a great job. Group bookings made in the second quarter for later in 2011 increased 18%, and long-term group bookings are returning. In the second quarter, we booked business for 2012 that was 19% higher than the prior year, and booked business for 2013 was 13% higher. In fact, nearly 1/4 of the group business booked in our second quarter were for the years 2014 and beyond. 
I'll stop at margins in the second quarter where domestic company-operated properties rose 100 basis points, reflecting higher occupancy and room rates. In international markets, gross profit margins benefited from strong REVPAR in most markets, increasing 160 basis points, excluding the Middle East and Japan markets. With good cost controls, we expect domestic cost profit margins increased 100 to 125 basis points, and international margins to increase roughly 150 basis points for the full year, and that's excluding the impact of the Middle East and Japan. 
Fee revenue rose 11% in the second quarter, with incentive fees up 9%. Incentive fee growth year-over-year was constrained by modestly lower incentive fees in the D.C. market and declines in incentive fees at hotels in the Middle East. Our owned and leased profits declined $2 million during -- due to lower hotel termination fees year-over-year and lower results at our leased hotels in Tokyo. Elsewhere, owned and leased hotels reported stronger results. 
For our Timeshare business, second quarter contract sales were a bit ahead of expectations. Compared to the prior year, Timeshare sales and services net declined due to lower interest income, and to a lesser extent, higher product costs. Compared to our expectations, lower Timeshare sales and services net reflected higher sales and marketing costs, as well as delays in revenue recognition associated with certain special promotions. 
G&A expenses rose 12% year-over-year in the second quarter, reflecting higher nonroutine workout costs, legal costs and approximately $3 million in expenses associated with the spinoff transaction. G&A also reflected higher costs associated with our international growth and routine compensation. 
Compared to our guidance, G&A was about $5 million to $10 million better than expected in the second quarter, largely due to our $5 million reversal of a loan loss provision and lower-than-expected workout costs, which we now believe will occur later in the year. 
Let's turn to guidance for the rest of the year. Our international REVPAR growth, even excluding the Middle East, is likely to slow a bit in the third quarter from the second quarter pace. The 2010 World Expo will be a top comp for our Shanghai hotel later this year. REVPAR growth in Europe is expected to moderate in the second half due to the timing of this year's fairs in Germany as well as tougher comparables. As a result, for the third quarter, we expect international systemwide REVPAR growth to total 6% to 8%, and that's excluding the Middle East and Japan. 
Given these trends for the full year, we expect international REVPAR to increase 7% to 9%, excluding the Middle East and Japan, a bit higher than last quarter's guidance due to the strong first half performance. 
With relatively more leisure in the third quarter, we expect North American systemwide REVPAR growth up 5% to 7%. We expect the fourth quarter to be modestly stronger, and therefore on a full year basis, still expect 6% to 8% REVPAR growth. 
For our Timeshare business in the third quarter, we expect contract sales to run slightly ahead of last year's adjusted levels. We assume Timeshare sales and services net to total $40 million to $45 million, with continued reductions in interest income as outstanding mortgage balances continue to decline. We expect Timeshare segment results to total $25 million to $30 million in the third quarter. 
For the full year 2011, we continue to expect contract sales to be slightly lower than the prior year adjusted amount. We assume Timeshare sales and services net to total about $205 million to $215 million. This is about $10 million lower than our prior full year expectations. About $5 million of this profit decline is related to lower revenue reportability, which we expect will be offset by higher reportability in '12. The other $5 million of the profit decline is mainly related to start-up costs for our banking and borrowing points and the Marriott Vacation Club points program. We expect Timeshare segments results to total about $140 million to $150 million for 2011. 
We expect our G&A expense for the full year to increase about 6% to 8% over adjusted levels in the prior year. This forecast reflects the -- reflects the nonroutine costs we talked about earlier, as well as higher spending for brand initiatives and the costs of our international growth market. 
Our full year G&A guidance is modestly higher than our forecast from last quarter, largely due to nearly $5 million in transaction expenses associated with the Timeshare spinoff recognized through the second quarter. We expect additional spinoff transactions in the second half, which could be material and which have not been included in our guidance. 
On this basis, for the full year, we expect earnings per share will increase 17% to 24% over the prior year adjusted EPS. We anticipate EBITDA will climb 9% to 13% compared to last year's adjusted amount. For simplicity, this guidance assumes the split will not occur until year end 2011 and again excludes future spinoff transaction costs. 
We assume about $500 million to $700 million in investment spending in 2011, including $50 million to $100 million in maintenance spending. We recently negotiated a 5-year extension to our bank revolver, which now has $1.75 billion of total capacity and doesn't mature until 2016. We repurchased over 18 million shares for over $675 million through the second quarter. We expect to remain aggressive, given our recent stock price and substantial investment capacity. 
Now to provide more details about the Vacation Ownership business and the pending transaction, I'd like to turn things over to Steve Weisz. Steve?

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Carl. This is an exciting time at Marriott Vacation Club. As we prepare to be an independent company, we've put a lot of thought into our future strategy. In our view, no one does vacation ownership better. We market our products by leveraging the
componenttext:
Thanks, Carl. This is an exciting time at Marriott Vacation Club. As we prepare to be an independent company, we've put a lot of thought into our future strategy. In our view, no one does vacation ownership better. We market our products by leveraging the strongest lodging brands and a world-class sales force. We execute against high customer expectations with outstanding products and services that encourages customers to buy yet more product.  And as a result, our more than 400,000 customers are very loyal and highly satisfied. 
We believe an independent Marriott Vacations worldwide will be attractive to shareholders for several reasons. First, we will be the largest public pure-play vacation ownership business. We have a highly skilled management team with an outstanding track record focused on this attractive business and an early stage of a recovery. 
Second, we see upside in the business. We are still in the early stages of the rollout of our Marriott Vacation Club Destinations Program. We continue to sign up existing owners, and our average contract sale continues to increase so there is still considerable upside as the program continues to gain traction with new owners. 
Third, we have strong liquidity and modest nonsecuritized debt. We recently demonstrated our resiliency in the deepest recessions with good cost control and strong cash flow, and further, we are well positioned to thrive regardless of the economic climate. 
Fourth, while we recognize the vacation ownership has historically been a capital-intensive business, our cash needs in the near term are quite modest. We have $1.3 billion of inventory, including $600 million of finished goods inventory. This will minimize our capital needs for the next few years. 
We also believe we can generate cash flow over time from the sale of excess assets, including some very attractive beachfront real estate. In fact, we expect to generate meaningful amounts of free cash flow for the foreseeable future. As our inventory declines over time, we intend to pursue asset-light expansion opportunities. We expect to leverage our management know-how to manage Timeshare operations for other brands and/or develop ancillary businesses to drive high margin recurring and stable revenues. We also expect to be able to develop new resorts by distressed inventory or enter into turnkey projects with third-party developers. Ours will be a resourceful and nimble company. It will quickly seize opportunities presented to us. 
We know there are many questions about the appropriate valuation for this new company. We're working on pro forma numbers for our new Timeshare company and expect to have forecast available when we do our roadshow this fall. For valuation, we recommend a sum of the parts approach given that we expect to have a material portion of our cash flow coming from strong and sustainable management fees and net financing income, as well as our development business. 
We look forward to meeting with as many of you as possible early this fall. With that, I'll turn things back to Arne.

componenttext: Sure, Dave. I think what we've talked about is that we expect the cash tax benefits to be several hundred million dollars. And just to clarify, that's cash taxes we've benefited over the years but this is inherently triggering those taxes as part of the spin. And a good portion of those will be recognized currently or will be benefited currently at the date of the spin, with the rest carried forward over the next several years. It's about half and half, David.

componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about your guidance for the back half of the year? The U.S. REVPAR guidance for the year of 6% to 8%, seems to imply a significant ramp in the fourth quarter, and if you're running at about 6% for the first 3 quarters, it seems l
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about your guidance for the back half of the year? The U.S. REVPAR guidance for the year of 6% to 8%, seems to imply a significant ramp in the fourth quarter, and if you're running at about 6% for the first 3 quarters, it seems like you need to do about 8% in the fourth quarter to hit the midpoint and 12% to hit the high end. Can you just talk about what gives you comfort with the ability to hit those numbers?

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Josh, it's Arne. I'm not sure exactly what numbers you're looking at but I've got North American systemwide Q2 actual is at 6.6%. And I think the Q1 number, which I don't have in front of me, was about in the same range. And so we are -- we're sittin
componenttext: Yes, Josh, it's Arne. I'm not sure exactly what numbers you're looking at but I've got North American systemwide Q2 actual is at 6.6%. And I think the Q1 number, which I don't have in front of me, was about in the same range. And so we are -- we're sitting close -- not quite at the midpoint of that 6% to 8% range but not too terribly far south of it. When you look at how the balance of the year, as Carl said in his comments, we expect Q3 to be maybe a little bit weaker than Q4, really fundamentally because it's a bit more of a leisure quarter than Q4 is. Obviously, we'd have to see how Q4 gets developed, and we're giving our best sense at this point but there's no guarantees at this. But we would expect that 6% to 8% range is still the right balance and expect that Q4 is going to be around the midpoint of that range, not dramatically different than that.

componenttext: Sure, Josh. We've incurred about $5 million so far. Going forward, we'll incur costs going forward. We don't have a number for you right now. But what we're anticipating is to have a better view for that probably at the end of August when we file the amended Form 10, and we'll give you those -- have a better feel for those numbers at that time.

And then specifically with those 3 areas you mentioned in the second quarter, Middle East, Japan and the Washington D.C. market, are you improving -- relatively improving REVPAR results throughout the course of the year? Or are you thinking about those 3 areas as performing in the second half much the way it has in the second quarter?

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll try and take a first crack at this, and then Carl can jump in correct me on the currency particularly. But I think the guidance we're giving you is essentially a constant dollar guidance.  And so by and large, we're not trying to get into the cu
componenttext: Yes, I'll try and take a first crack at this, and then Carl can jump in correct me on the currency particularly. But I think the guidance we're giving you is essentially a constant dollar guidance.  And so by and large, we're not trying to get into the currency forecasting business and give you currency-adjusted REVPAR numbers. With respect to the Middle East and D.C., Middle East, Japan and D.C. Let's start with D.C., which is more material to us than the Middle East and Japan are. D.C., as we mentioned a quarter ago, our distribution in D.C. is a bit over 2x the industry's distribution in D.C. So it moves a bit larger for our average statistics. We have been a bit disappointed so far the balance of the year to see D.C. essentially performing flat to last year. Carl mentioned the good news in D.C., which is that it's one of the market which is at about at peak REVPAR and not surprisingly, that's because the business of government and security and national defense and all that has been a relatively robust part of our economy for the last number of years and was not hit nearly as bad in the recession as many other aspects of the U.S. economy. I think now we would say that we expect D.C. to continue to bump along at kind of flat levels through the balance of the year, and that's implicit in our guidance. We have not really talked about 2012 yet, and we don't have any budgets or anything else that gives us tremendous insight into 2012. So without the benefit of a careful look at group business on the books and some of those things, it's hard to give you a real clear number. But I would guess that the budget conversations and threats to the federal budget, as well as the presidential election, which will increasingly take center stage next year, neither of those are great fins for business in D.C. for 2012.  And so we would get the D.C. is going to continue to be a fairly modest market, at least in terms of year-over-year performance. Middle East and Japan are obviously very different markets. Japan is -- we've got the leading hotel from a REVPAR perspective in Tokyo, which is the Ritz-Carlton. And it has suffered as many hotels in Japan have, both because of less inbound travel by the intercontinental traveler, and beyond that, by a sense of reduced economic activity and maybe a even a little sense of mourning in Japan. We're starting to see some of those trends reverse. So the F&B business, for example, essentially disappeared early after the earthquake and tsunami. We're starting to see some signs of life in that and see that come back. We're seeing occupancy build. But we expect that even in the fourth quarter, we will be -- oh I suspect on average 20% to 30% REVPAR down from the fourth quarter of 2010. Now that's a lot better than where we've been since the early months of the post-disaster over there but still a long way to where we were before. Middle East, very different markets. I think Egypt, I was there a few weeks ago, that's to see our team, you get a sense for what's going on in the ground there. Egypt is a fabulous destination, and there's every reason to believe that it will come back. Many markets in D.C. though are -- excuse me, in Egypt are driven by wholesalers, often coming out of Europe. That Wholesale business is not likely to come back with significance, and so there has been sustained stability in that market. We haven't seen that yet, and so we would both expect in the guidance that we've given and as a predictive matter, that Egypt is probably a 12- to 18-month recovery story. It's not a 3- to 6-month recovery story. Other markets in the Middle East are very different so you look at Dubai. Dubai has net benefited in some respects from this. Bahrain is obviously quite weak. We're not in Syria but we are in Jordan. Jordan is not as bad as Egypt and in many respects is more stable. But generally, I think implicit in our guidance is a pretty slow recovery for the region as a whole.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just maybe want to start off with Arne, in your opening remarks, you mentioned a little bit about profitability per room taking a little bit longer, and I don't want to completely nitpick here, but am wondering just what you meant by a little longer, kind
componenttext: Just maybe want to start off with Arne, in your opening remarks, you mentioned a little bit about profitability per room taking a little bit longer, and I don't want to completely nitpick here, but am wondering just what you meant by a little longer, kind of in that? Is that longer than your original expectation or just longer, given kind of something else you're seeing? Or but how does that compare to your original plan or what you laid out in the Analyst Day?

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's no change from what we had -- what we had contemplated and talked  about at the analyst meeting. And longer refers only to in comparison to REVPAR. So when you look at the REVPAR numbers, and we've talked about D.C. a little bit in this call, obvious
componenttext: It's no change from what we had -- what we had contemplated and talked  about at the analyst meeting. And longer refers only to in comparison to REVPAR. So when you look at the REVPAR numbers, and we've talked about D.C. a little bit in this call, obviously, D.C. is roughly at peak REVPAR already. You look at the U.S. as a whole, and clearly the U.S. as a whole is not back to peak REVPAR but we can see it.  And it's not far out. So a year or 18 months or 2 years, probably worse case from now, we're looking at most markets in the United States being to peak REVPAR. But that's not enough to get us back to peak profitability, either for hotel owners or for Marriott.  And obviously, our models differ a little bit. We're going to be fee-driven. They're going to be driven by the profit margins in those hotels.  And that's what's going to take a little bit longer. I don't have a date for you on that but we would have a reasonably high level of confidence as we would have in prior cycles that within a couple of years or so after peak REVPAR, we should be approaching in many markets peak profitability.  And we look forward to seeing how that works its way through. And obviously, in the context of that, I also talked about the tremendous unit growth, which will also be adding certainly to our system and our profitability as we go forward.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's helpful.  And then my second question was on you mentioned both in the prepared remarks and then one of the answers one of the questions about leisure business being a little bit slower, and part of the driver of that in the third quarter. I think
componenttext: That's helpful.  And then my second question was on you mentioned both in the prepared remarks and then one of the answers one of the questions about leisure business being a little bit slower, and part of the driver of that in the third quarter. I think generally speaking, we've all seen either the June and July REVPAR numbers slow a little bit sequentially. So I guess is it your take that, that is mostly kind of a customer and demographics shift? Have you seen any changes on the group business behavior you gave some good booking statistics. But just curious if you've seen like is it just a real dichotomy there that's going to probably going to continue as we pick about the recovery? Because it seems a little different than maybe we've seen in past cycles?

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. In fact, the use of the word dichotomy, I think, is would substantially overstate what we're talking about in terms of relatively softer Q3 than Q4. If anything, we've been very heartened by the strength of leisure business. Now let's back up and stat
componenttext: No. In fact, the use of the word dichotomy, I think, is would substantially overstate what we're talking about in terms of relatively softer Q3 than Q4. If anything, we've been very heartened by the strength of leisure business. Now let's back up and state the obvious. Leisure travel is more price-sensitive than business travel, surprise, surprise. Notwithstanding that, I think most of the leisure business, which is driven in our hotels, is probably coming out of the higher wealth demographic as a consequence that a persistent high unemployment, the weakness in the construction trades and the like is probably less relevant currently than what we're seeing in leisure demand. But leisure demand is going to be more influenced by pricing and by consumer sentiment and those sorts of things. And as a consequence, we see it be a little bit weaker but still pretty healthy on a year-over-year basis and are quite gratified by what we've seen so far. I think all things considered, what we're communicating today is a steady as she goes report. What we see is a broad recovery that's underway. It is playing out in many respects the way exactly we would expect it to play out. So business trends in travel is the strongest, showing great performance year-over-year both in terms of pricing and in terms of volume. We're seeing group bookings build steadily, and Carl gave you some of the statistics. We're up -- bookings in Q2 were up anywhere from up roughly 15% to roughly 20% depending on whether you're looking at bookings for Q3 or Q4 in 2012 or 2013, et cetera. Good healthy year-over-year growth and good leisure performance.  And so we made very much to be reiterating the high-single-digits 6% to 8% REVPAR growth that we've talked about a quarter ago. And we'd really not add any caution with the exception of the stories we've talked about in Middle East, Japan and D.C. And to state the obvious, we are reading the same newspapers that you all are reading, and if some of these newspapers lead to slower GDP growth than any of us anticipated, that will have an impact ultimately on business travel and the rest of it but we're not seeing that show up in our business today.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And just one last maybe for Carl, you brought down the high end of your North American hotel margin guidance but you maintained the North American REVPAR full year targets. So just wondering, is that a function of mix or kind of what are y
componenttext: That's helpful. And just one last maybe for Carl, you brought down the high end of your North American hotel margin guidance but you maintained the North American REVPAR full year targets. So just wondering, is that a function of mix or kind of what are you seeing that's bringing down that a little bit just as you think about things from the owner's perspective and that's it for me.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's probably a little sensitivity around D.C., and we probably, as a result, tightened the range a little bit. That's all, really.
componenttext: Sure. It's probably a little sensitivity around D.C., and we probably, as a result, tightened the range a little bit. That's all, really.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Patrick Scholes of FBR Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Patrick Scholes of FBR Capital Markets.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: In your prepared remarks, you had mentioned that group REVPAR during the second quarter was up only about 2%. Just a couple of questions in that regard. In D.C., that sort of that lower growth rate function of just groups burning off that were booked at l
componenttext: In your prepared remarks, you had mentioned that group REVPAR during the second quarter was up only about 2%. Just a couple of questions in that regard. In D.C., that sort of that lower growth rate function of just groups burning off that were booked at lower rates in '09 and '10 and additionally of new groups being booked, what are some of the headwinds to pricing power that you're seeing right now for as it relates to groups?

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have -- we sliced and diced that in more ways than you'd like to now. When we look at the Q2 stayed and paid, and that's what that roughly 2% growth is looking at. Again, it's not looking at bookings in Q2 but it's looking at bookings that came in
componenttext: Yes, we have -- we sliced and diced that in more ways than you'd like to now. When we look at the Q2 stayed and paid, and that's what that roughly 2% growth is looking at. Again, it's not looking at bookings in Q2 but it's looking at bookings that came in the books. It shouldn't surprise you to know that the weakest business was the business that was booked 2 and 3 years ago. So when we look at business booked 2 years ago stayed in our second quarter, it was down almost 10%. It shouldn't surprise you because 2 years ago, we were really wrestling with fairly dark days in the economy. 3 years ago wasn't quite as bad, even though actually, if you look at the stock market, the stock market was probably worse 3 years ago than it was 2 years ago, and that's probably a little bit that folks making decisions about group business are not responding necessarily to what they see on the Dow that day, but a little bit it take some time for them to react. And so when we look instead at business booked more recently, it is meaningfully better than those weak numbers. But again fundamentally, and this is in the prepared comments, we talked about it a couple of quarters ago, it takes a while to build the book of group business. And as a consequence, we're not surprised to see it, the stayed and paid REVPAR group numbers lower than the Transient numbers, and we do expect that those will build over time as we get the benefit of that plus 15% to 20% group revenue booked in Q2 as it ultimately shows up in our hotels.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011

componenttext: Arne, you were saying earlier that fee revenues were 6% from D.C. and 13% incentive fees from D.C. Could you give us the same numbers for the Middle East and Japan? And then I'm curious about India. If the last time you had some tariff activity in Mumbai, there were spillover to other places in India from a hotel perspective.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll let Carl pull and double check this, and I think -- let me talk about India first, we're obviously saddened to read about and hear about yesterday, the events that took place in Mumbai. From my recollection, the impact of the last event in Mumbai in
componenttext: I'll let Carl pull and double check this, and I think -- let me talk about India first, we're obviously saddened to read about and hear about yesterday, the events that took place in Mumbai. From my recollection, the impact of the last event in Mumbai in India and around the region in terms of REVPAR was not significant. Obviously, it had some impact in Mumbai itself but that was not long-lasting and viewed as an isolated event and not as a turmoil that kept people away for some period of time. We'll have to see the way that this develops after the events of yesterday. But provided it is a single tariff event on one day, that does not sort of recur soon, and repeatedly, we would not expect that the impact would be significant. I think on gross Middle East fees full year is about 1% of our gross fees. Carl?

componenttext: Yes, it's normal years. So you could see the effect that, that had on the percentage that we ended up reporting at 9%.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. Just one further question. As you look at the corporate side, what are you thinking about rate negotiations going into the fall? And then as you look at the group side, how are the rollouts of sales force one and your group in yield system going?
componenttext: Great. Just one further question. As you look at the corporate side, what are you thinking about rate negotiations going into the fall? And then as you look at the group side, how are the rollouts of sales force one and your group in yield system going?

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: So special corporate negotiate obviously, we're not underway yet, and we'll have to see the way the economy develops, and I think get a better read as we go forward. I think generally, we have seen good rate growth this year compared to 2010 but we still
componenttext: So special corporate negotiate obviously, we're not underway yet, and we'll have to see the way the economy develops, and I think get a better read as we go forward. I think generally, we have seen good rate growth this year compared to 2010 but we still see special corporate rates, which are double digits down from peak levels, varies a little bit account to account but I think we're likely to see fairly healthy rate growth in 2012 compared to 2011 if the economic recovery continues the way it appears to be. Sales transformation and some of that sale systems we've rolled out, I think we remain quite confident in a long term, encouraged by the early -- early anecdotes that coming back out of the system. To be fair, the last 2 regions in the United States, we rolled out in June so they've just got up and running.  And so we're now, for the first time in the position where we've got sales transformation across the entire United States. Among the positive things we're seeing, we measure a business that is pitched and caught outside of one region into another, and that business is almost 50% more than we would have anticipated and a very healthy contribution. But to be fair, it's still very early in the process. And so you will not see us or hear us on the aircraft carrier deck claiming victory yet. We think that's probably another some months or some quarters away but we feel good about the way it's going so far.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011

componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering with regards to the group REVPAR growth. You mentioned 2% growth in the second quarter. I think STR's estimate for your fiscal quarter would've been closer to 8% for group. Do your properties typically have a longer lead booking time th
componenttext: I'm just wondering with regards to the group REVPAR growth. You mentioned 2% growth in the second quarter. I think STR's estimate for your fiscal quarter would've been closer to 8% for group. Do your properties typically have a longer lead booking time than the average upper upscale segment property? And maybe that's one of the disparities where you had more groups that were booked in advance 2 years ago during that terrible economic time that you discussed earlier?

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: I am absolutely certain that, that's a piece of it. So we are -- the bigger we are, and we know we are bigger than any of our principal competitors, maybe with the exception of Gaylord, which obviously is a very different kind of company. But the bigger t
componenttext: I am absolutely certain that, that's a piece of it. So we are -- the bigger we are, and we know we are bigger than any of our principal competitors, maybe with the exception of Gaylord, which obviously is a very different kind of company. But the bigger the hotel, the bigger the meeting, the longer the lead time. We, I think, dominate the association space. The association meeting business is probably often 2, 3, 4 even 5 years booked in advance, and that long window may have some relevance. I'm not sure where you're getting that 8% number but a piece of that could also be market-driven or comp hotel-driven. So you've got group business which has grown a bit more but has also been spread across some new hotels. New hotels and some are in our system, many are in other brand system so that may also go into that equation.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: That makes perfect sense. So given that longer lead time for your properties? Do you have -- what percentage of your group bookings are actually on the books right now for 4Q? I would imagine the vast majority of them are already on the books then. For 4Q
componenttext: That makes perfect sense. So given that longer lead time for your properties? Do you have -- what percentage of your group bookings are actually on the books right now for 4Q? I would imagine the vast majority of them are already on the books then. For 4Q? For the fourth year of this year? And then any idea if you can give us any color on how that rate growth is looking versus 4Q last year for those groups, that would be helpful too.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would guess we're probably about 90% of the books for the fourth quarter, average MHR Hotel, Marriott Hotel Resorts & Hotel. I don't know if any of us here have got the rate versus occupancy. I would hazard a guess that it is low-single-digits, maybe ge
componenttext: I would guess we're probably about 90% of the books for the fourth quarter, average MHR Hotel, Marriott Hotel Resorts & Hotel. I don't know if any of us here have got the rate versus occupancy. I would hazard a guess that it is low-single-digits, maybe getting towards mid-single-digits revenue growth compared to last year's group business on the books at the same time for the fourth quarter of '10.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just one final quick question. I'm just hoping that, I don't know, maybe Carl, maybe Steve can answer the question. When you guys switched over to the points-based Timeshare model, I was under the impression that we were going to see virtually no
componenttext: And then just one final quick question. I'm just hoping that, I don't know, maybe Carl, maybe Steve can answer the question. When you guys switched over to the points-based Timeshare model, I was under the impression that we were going to see virtually no deferred revenues going forward. Obviously, one of the challenges in this quarter with Timeshare was deferred revenue. Can you give us some color as to why this quarter had a larger-than-expected Timeshare? I know you mentioned something with regards to the points-based program or the Marriott Rewards point specifically.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll have John Geller here, who's going to be the CFO of the new Timeshare business, have him answer that.
componenttext: I'll have John Geller here, who's going to be the CFO of the new Timeshare business, have him answer that.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's different components of the deferred revenue. I think where you're not going to see the deferred revenue anymore is around percentage complete. We're putting completed inventory in. So in the past, we would have deferred revenue as we completed pr
componenttext: There's different components of the deferred revenue. I think where you're not going to see the deferred revenue anymore is around percentage complete. We're putting completed inventory in. So in the past, we would have deferred revenue as we completed projects that would come in. So that's the piece that's virtually is gone. From a timing perspective, quarter-to-quarter, there is still some deferred revenue and it really relates primarily to our finance sales, where you're required to have 10% down. And for GAAP reporting, you also need to cover your first aid benefits or some sales incentives that we get to customers at the closing table. In the second quarter, for example, we ran some sales incentives and offered some higher first aid benefits.  And as a result, we didn't have that 10% down for GAAP. So some of those sales, even though our sales for the second quarter, at least for Timeshare were flat year-over-year, our deferred revenue was slightly higher for the quarter because of some of that. And we'll see that flip around here in the third and fourth quarter. Some of it will slide, I think, in the next year a little bit too.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Harry Curtis of Nomura.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Harry Curtis of Nomura.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: If you could maybe put a little bit more meat on the bone as far as the difference between your domestic full-service REVPAR, which was up 5.4% and the Smith Travel upper upscale which was up closer to 7%. I think some of it about 50 basis points, you asc
componenttext: If you could maybe put a little bit more meat on the bone as far as the difference between your domestic full-service REVPAR, which was up 5.4% and the Smith Travel upper upscale which was up closer to 7%. I think some of it about 50 basis points, you ascribed to D.C.  And my first question is, are you able to quantify the impact of renovations on the quarter? We talked about the group side but is there any quantification of the differential? And what we're getting a fair amount of in response to this is that again, that you're losing share to your competitors. And I wonder if you could just comment with the specifics on why you don't think you're losing share to competitors?

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I will. And the short answer is we're not losing share to our competitors. So when you look at the Marriott Hotels & Resorts brand, and we'll focus -- I'll focus my comments on that brand, which is obviously, substantial for us and bellwether brand f
componenttext: Yes, I will. And the short answer is we're not losing share to our competitors. So when you look at the Marriott Hotels & Resorts brand, and we'll focus -- I'll focus my comments on that brand, which is obviously, substantial for us and bellwether brand for us. We build our REVPAR index by hotel, with each hotel looking at typically 5 or 6 hotels, which would be within its competitive set. Overwhelmingly, those hotels are in the same market. Occasionally, you'll find a resort hotel which might have a hotel that's outside of it, same geographic market, but 98%, I suppose,  of the MHR hotels, their competitive sets will be entirely located within the same geography. Every period or every month, we report, as do most of our competitors in the United States, this is less the case outside the United States to Smith Travel.  And Smith Travel spits back the result of all of that data and tells us whether we are taking or losing share. Since the recession began in late 2007 or early 2008, the Marriott brand has taken about 4 points of index which is massive. Why did it take index? Well hopefully, a part of it is because of great things we're doing around customer-focused things, around product-focused things, about brand innovation, about renovations and the like. But clearly, we were also helped by the cyclicality of group business where we had group business on the books more than our competitors did because we're bigger shops and benefited from some of those bookings that were done before the recession hit.  And as a consequence, our REVPAR did not decline as much as the average Smith Travel did. Now as we look at 2011 year-to-date and we adjust for renovations, we see that the MHR brand is down a few tenths of one percentage point. We think that, that is actually pretty encouraging because of this cyclicality in group business that we know to occur at this state of the recovery. In many respects, we would expect to be losing -- losing share that could be measurable and a few tenths of one point, there's not volatility in these numbers that it's effectively nearly 0. And so as we sit here today, we have tremendous confidence, not only that we have taken massive share over the last 3 or 4 years, but that we are competing very well.  And what's driving the difference in these headline numbers is, by and large, a function of geographic distribution of these hotels and not a function of any share index performance.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: What other markets in addition to D.C. are you more concentrated in than your competitors that could account for the 100 basis points of difference?
componenttext: What other markets in addition to D.C. are you more concentrated in than your competitors that could account for the 100 basis points of difference?

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're a much big -- it obviously depends on which brand you're measuring it against. Marriott brand is bigger than most of the full-service brands so we're going to tend to have more suburban hotels. We're probably going tend to have more secondary market
componenttext: We're a much big -- it obviously depends on which brand you're measuring it against. Marriott brand is bigger than most of the full-service brands so we're going to tend to have more suburban hotels. We're probably going tend to have more secondary market hotels. I know among our markets where we have disproportionate market share, we've got Detroit, we've got Atlanta, we've got Washington D.C. And you'd have to go and look at data to see about how those markets perform exactly and how they perform to the first couple of quarters this year. The suburban piece though, I think, is going to be significant. So a quarter ago, we've talked about D.C. hotels, and I think one of our competitors came out and said, "Well, we own a hotel in D.C. and it didn't do so badly." We've got 100 hotels in D.C. and the JW Marriott Downtown at 14th and Pennsylvania Avenue owned by Host, great hotel. I don't have the performance of every hotel right here in front of me but the Downtown hotel in Washington, which is trading at a higher end performed better in the second quarter than the average across the market because you look at Crystal City, which is going to be dominated by government business, it's going to have big competing hotels in Crystal City, and that's going to be a much more hard hit area than the JW Marriott hotel or the Ritz-Carlton on the west side of Washington D.C.  And unless you look at this competitive set data, the REVPAR index data, you're not getting anything meaningful by looking at the performance of MHR against Smith Travel's upper upscale because you're going to be comparing apples and oranges.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: And so if you were to hazard a guess in the next 2 or 3 quarters, when would you or how long do you think it would -- it's going to take to see your full-service domestic REVPAR begin to match up closer to the Smith Travel data?
componenttext: And so if you were to hazard a guess in the next 2 or 3 quarters, when would you or how long do you think it would -- it's going to take to see your full-service domestic REVPAR begin to match up closer to the Smith Travel data?

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's a great question, Harry, and I don't have a very informed answer. But taking a feel of the pieces, you can tell from the comments about D.C., we'd expect D.C. is going to tend to hold us back here, probably through the presidential election. If you l
componenttext: It's a great question, Harry, and I don't have a very informed answer. But taking a feel of the pieces, you can tell from the comments about D.C., we'd expect D.C. is going to tend to hold us back here, probably through the presidential election. If you look simply at that measure that you're talking about. Why? Because we've got twice as many, more than twice as many hotels in D.C. as the industry does on average. And if we're right about D.C., which is it's going to continue to sort of bounce along that performance, that is going to tend to be a market which causes our average number to be different than the Smith Travel number. Again, I think that is a much too rough measure to look at and is essentially meaningless. The measure to look at is how are we performing against the hotels we compete against by market and how we're performing exceedingly well.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from Steve Kent of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can we just talk a little bit more about the weakness in Timeshare? I guess I'm just struggling with it. If you have sold so much Timeshare and there's greater deferred revenue, when would that be made up? Why is it -- why would it take even into 2012 for
componenttext: Can we just talk a little bit more about the weakness in Timeshare? I guess I'm just struggling with it. If you have sold so much Timeshare and there's greater deferred revenue, when would that be made up? Why is it -- why would it take even into 2012 for that to happen? And also on that same one, the Timeshare, it seems looks you are selling many more weeks to existing customers. And at what point do you start to max out the sales to existing customers?

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: David, this is Steve Weisz. Let me try to answer question. First of all, on the contract sales side, if you look at our Timeshare, let's leave the fractional and the whole ownership residential piece out. In the second quarter, we did exactly what we did
componenttext: David, this is Steve Weisz. Let me try to answer question. First of all, on the contract sales side, if you look at our Timeshare, let's leave the fractional and the whole ownership residential piece out. In the second quarter, we did exactly what we did in 2010. So the deferred piece that John referred to is not the fact that we had sales in the second quarter that won't be reportable until the first quarter of 2012. It's the fact that the second quarter sales might be reportable in Q3 or Q4. But if you continue doing the kinds of promotions which we believe we will be doing at least in the near term, that some of the sales that will happen in Q3 or Q4 will spill over into Q1 of next year. So it's just kind of the cascading effect of that. And so I think that's the first answer to your question. The second answer to your question is 39% of our sales year-to-date are to first-time buyers, which implies a 61% are obviously to our existing customers. That's been very deliberate on our part. We have -- we made it a focus, we made it a strategic decision that when we launched the points business in June of 2010, that we really wanted to get in front of every single one of our existing owners to try to help them understand the relative merits of them joining Marriott Vacation Club Destinations. So as we have allocated to our flow and trying to, in fact, take advantage of talking to people while they're on vacation at our resorts, we have squeezed out towards the first-time buyers. That was very deliberate, and we said we would do that. As we start to move further into this year, now having a year behind us, we will have talked to a lot of those customers. We would expect that over time, that we will start to see the percentage of first-time buyers come back to a more normalized percentage. You may recall that roughly 50% of our business over the years has been to first-time buyers, and roughly 50% of our business has been to existing owners and their referrals. So I think it's -- what we've seen is playing out exactly what we wanted to do. We're very pleased with the receptiveness that our existing owners have had to joining Marriott Vacation Club Destinations, our Points Program. And we're not at all concerned about the long-term implications of that.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: But Steve, I guess what I'm struggling with is the essential case then why the need to offer so much more in Marriott Reward Points and other incentives to get people to purchase if the product is as good as we all know and the customers have a high prope
componenttext: But Steve, I guess what I'm struggling with is the essential case then why the need to offer so much more in Marriott Reward Points and other incentives to get people to purchase if the product is as good as we all know and the customers have a high propensity to buy, especially the existing ones? So why the need to roll out that program? That's what doesn't add up for me.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, part of it is we made a very calculated effort in 2009 and '10 to throttle back on financing. That was a cash flow decision on our part where we decided that we would really kind of try to de-emphasize financing. We've actually been able to bring ou
componenttext: Well, part of it is we made a very calculated effort in 2009 and '10 to throttle back on financing. That was a cash flow decision on our part where we decided that we would really kind of try to de-emphasize financing. We've actually been able to bring our financing propensity back up to more normalized notion than the mid-40s, and part of that is what the effect that John talked about is, when you offer -- when you take the financing piece which then -- and then you take the first aid benefit which comes off of a finance sale to get you less than the 10% downpayment, it's that you take a certain number of payments on a monthly basis to get you back over the 10% to have it be reportable. That's really the issue there.

headline: Marriott International, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're out of time and I'm going to jump in here but I think one of the other things that as response to your question, Steve Kent, is that a year ago and 1.5 year ago, Steve Weisz and his team were doing more with peer discounting of the pricing of the Ti
componenttext: We're out of time and I'm going to jump in here but I think one of the other things that as response to your question, Steve Kent, is that a year ago and 1.5 year ago, Steve Weisz and his team were doing more with peer discounting of the pricing of the Timeshare mix. We've not only eliminated that discounting but many respects pound for pound, we have increased pricing.  And there is some promotional activity, which is a way of addressing a piece of that to make sure that we still got a value proposition and a pitch for the customer that is an attractive one.  And we think that's the decisions they've made in that space are good. You are not hearing Steve Weisz say or any of us say that consumer confidence is back to a level which gives us the confidence to believe that we can sell as much weekly Timeshare as we were selling in 2006 and 2007. And to get back to those levels is going to require a continuing recovery in the economy and a continuing recovery in consumer confidence.  And as those things happen, we'll see that this business continues to grow. But none of us is sitting here saying we feel so good about this product that we don't have to do promotional activity, and we can sort of sit back and play hard to get and the customer's going to come in and buy more of this stuff than we can produce because that's not where we are yet in this economic recovery. I want to thank all of you for your time and interest this morning. We're obviously standing by to take any follow-up questions, and we'll be in touch with you as we can be of help to you. In the meantime, enjoy the balance of your summer. Come and see us. Stay with us. Talk to you soon. Bye.
